message_text: Paper Title: Strong Structural Controllability of Boolean Networks: Polynomial-Time Criteria, Minimal Node Control, and Distributed Pinning Strategies Paper Abstract: In this article, we initiate the strong structural controllability of Boolean networks (BNs), in order to cope with the difficulty of identifying intricate nodal dynamics. The derived necessary and sufficient criteria for the strong structural controllability of BNs are checkable in a polynomial amount of time. As an interesting feature, controllability is shown to be equivalent to fixed-time controllability in the network-structure regard. We further explore the minimal strong structural controllability problem of BNs that, reduced from the minimum vertex cover problem of graphs, consequently turns out to be NP-hard. More worthy implications are that our results on the strong structural controllability also serve as the basis to improve several existing approaches to a certain extent. First, the network aggregation subject to the controllability of BNs is provided where the aggregated blocks, except the rooted blocks, are strongly structurally controllable. Second, the pinning controllers are carried out to render an arbitrary BN controllable through node-to-node message exchange in a distributed form while traditional results only check the controllability of BNs with the preassigned controllers. Notably, the time complexity to design such controllers reduces to be only exponential with the maximal in-degree of pinned nodes rather than the node number of networks. As for the stochastic counterpart, upon the equivalence between the asymptotic stability of stochastic BNs and the criteria of strong structural controllability, we also further facilitate the design of distributed controllers to asymptotically stabilize stochastic BNs in probability. "contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.) "survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work) task - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding) method - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction) data - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus) artifact - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9) tool - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope) concept - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory) other - Entities that don't fit above categories uses - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks) proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS: - ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work) - CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new) { "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey", "triples": [ { "name": "Wikipedia Article Title", "relation": "uses|proposes", "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other", "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...", "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)" } ] } FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool: CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do. 1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field. 2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation. 3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia. 4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm") - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes) - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/) - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters 5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py 6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes. When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter: WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"]) This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains. Begin now.

Here are the search results for "controllability control systems":

## Key Findings

**Definition of Controllability:**
Complete state controllability describes the ability of an external input (the vector of control variables) to move the internal state of a system from any initial state to any final state in a finite time interval. More simply, controllability describes our ability to guide a dynamical system from any initial state to any desired final state in finite time, with a suitable choice of inputs.

**Related Concepts:**
Controllability and observability are dual notions. Controllability pertains to regulating the state by a choice of a suitable input, while observability pertains to being able to know the state by observing the output.

**Types of Controllability:**
Collective controllability is the ability to simultaneously steer a collection of dynamical systems, trajectory controllability is the ability to steer along a predefined trajectory rather than just to a desired final state, and output controllability is the ability to steer to specified values of the output.

**Testing Controllability:**
A continuous time-invariant linear state-space model is controllable if and only if the rank of the matrix [B AB A²B ... A^(n-1)B] equals n, where n is the number of state variables.

**Applications:**
Controllability and observability are studied as important aspects in control theory.

Links: [{"title":"Controllability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Controllability"},{"title":"Controllability Gramian - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Controllability_Gramian"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Observability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observability"},{"title":"Network controllability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_controllability"},{"title":"Control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_system"},{"title":"Coherent control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coherent_control"},{"title":"Stochastic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_control"},{"title":"Control-Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"State-space representation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State-space_representation"}]

Here are the search results for "controllability control systems":

## Key Findings

**Definition of Controllability:**
Complete state controllability describes the ability of an external input (the vector of control variables) to move the internal state of a system from any initial state to any final state in a finite time interval. More simply, controllability describes our ability to guide a dynamical system from any initial state to any desired final state in finite time, with a suitable choice of inputs.

**Related Concepts:**
Controllability and observability are dual notions. Controllability pertains to regulating the state by a choice of a suitable input, while observability pertains to being able to know the state by observing the output.

**Types of Controllability:**
Collective controllability is the ability to simultaneously steer a collection of dynamical systems, trajectory controllability is the ability to steer along a predefined trajectory rather than just to a desired final state, and output controllability is the ability to steer to specified values of the output.

**Testing Controllability:**
A continuous time-invariant linear state-space model is controllable if and only if the rank of the matrix [B AB A²B ... A^(n-1)B] equals n, where n is the number of state variables.

**Applications:**
Controllability and observability are studied as important aspects in control theory.

Based on the web search results for "pinning control consensus," I found several relevant topics:

## Key Results:

**Consensus Dynamics and Control:**
Consensus dynamics, also known as agreement dynamics, is an area of research at the intersection of systems theory and graph theory that studies how a group of agents—such as robots, sensors, or decision-makers—interacting over a network can reach a common decision or estimate through local rules and information exchange.(no content)Consensus dynamics has applications in areas such as physiological systems, gene regulatory networks, large-scale energy systems, and coordinated control of autonomous vehicle fleets on land, in the air, or in space.

**Pinning in Control Systems:**
The search results show that "pinning" in the context of control theory relates to the constraint or fixing of certain nodes or agents to specific values. This is often studied within consensus dynamics to understand how controlling certain nodes affects the overall system convergence.

**Processor Affinity (CPU Pinning):**
Processor affinity, also called CPU pinning or cache affinity, enables the binding and unbinding of a process or a thread to a central processing unit (CPU) or a range of CPUs, so that the process or thread will execute only on the designated CPU or CPUs rather than any CPU.

If you're looking for more specific information about a particular application of "pinning control consensus" (such as in a specific field or research area), please let me know and I can search for more detailed results.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "vertex cover graph theory"

Links: [{"title":"Vertex cover - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vertex_cover"},{"title":"Vertex cover in hypergraphs - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vertex_cover_in_hypergraphs"},{"title":"Vertex (graph theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vertex_(graph_theory)"},{"title":"Vertex cycle cover - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vertex_cycle_cover"},{"title":"Kőnig's theorem (graph theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/K%C5%91nig's_theorem_(graph_theory)"},{"title":"Covering graph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Covering_graph"},{"title":"Well-covered graph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Well-covered_graph"},{"title":"Set cover problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Set_cover_problem"},{"title":"Edge cycle cover - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edge_cycle_cover"},{"title":"Path cover - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Path_cover"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about vertex cover in graph theory:

## Definition

In graph theory, a vertex cover (sometimes node cover) of a graph is a set of vertices that includes at least one endpoint of every edge of the graph.

## Computational Complexity

The problem of finding a minimum vertex cover is a classical optimization problem that is NP-hard, so it cannot be solved by a polynomial-time algorithm if P ≠ NP.(no content)The decision version, the vertex cover problem, was one of Karp's 21 NP-complete problems and is therefore a classical NP-complete problem in computational complexity theory.

## Special Cases

For bipartite graphs, the equivalence between vertex cover and maximum matching described by Kőnig's theorem allows the bipartite vertex cover problem to be solved in polynomial time.(no content)For tree graphs, an algorithm finds a minimal vertex cover in polynomial time by finding the first leaf in the tree and adding its parent to the minimal vertex cover, then deleting the leaf and parent and all associated edges and continuing repeatedly until no edges remain in the tree.

## Approximation Algorithms

It has several simple 2-factor approximations and is a typical example of an NP-hard optimization problem that has an approximation algorithm.

## Practical Applications

A commercial establishment interested in installing the fewest possible closed circuit cameras covering all hallways (edges) connecting all rooms (nodes) on a floor might model the objective as a vertex cover minimization problem.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "asymptotic stability dynamical systems"

Links: [{"title":"Stability theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stability_theory"},{"title":"Lyapunov stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_stability"},{"title":"Exponential stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exponential_stability"},{"title":"Dynamical system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamical_system"},{"title":"Control-Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"LaSalle's invariance principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LaSalle's_invariance_principle"},{"title":"Synchronization of chaos - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synchronization_of_chaos"},{"title":"Input-to-state stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input-to-state_stability"},{"title":"Dynamical systems theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamical_systems_theory"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about asymptotic stability in dynamical systems:

## Definition

Asymptotic stability means that solutions that start close enough not only remain close enough but also eventually converge to the equilibrium.

## Key Characteristics

For asymptotic stability, the state is also required to converge to the zero state. This is a stronger requirement than mere stability, which only requires solutions to remain close to an equilibrium point.

## Testing for Asymptotic Stability

### Linear Systems

For solutions of a system with first-order constant coefficient linear differential equations, asymptotic stability is achieved as t → ∞ if and only if for all eigenvalues λ of the system matrix A, Re(λ) < 0.

### Nonlinear Systems

A general way to establish Lyapunov stability or asymptotic stability of a dynamical system is by means of Lyapunov functions.(no content)Lyapunov functions, named after Aleksandr Lyapunov, are scalar functions that may be used to prove the stability of an equilibrium of an ODE and are important to stability theory of dynamical systems and control theory.

## Related Concepts

Exponential stability is a form of asymptotic stability, valid for more general dynamical systems. Additionally, LaSalle's invariance principle is a criterion for the asymptotic stability of an autonomous (possibly nonlinear) dynamical system.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Asymptotic stability means that solutions that start close enough not only remain close enough but also eventually converge to the equilibrium.

## Key Characteristics

For asymptotic stability, the state is also required to converge to the zero state. This is a stronger requirement than mere stability, which only requires solutions to remain close to an equilibrium point.

## Testing for Asymptotic Stability

### Linear Systems

For solutions of a system with first-order constant coefficient linear differential equations, asymptotic stability is achieved as t → ∞ if and only if for all eigenvalues λ of the system matrix A, Re(λ) < 0.

### Nonlinear Systems

A general way to establish Lyapunov stability or asymptotic stability of a dynamical system is by means of Lyapunov functions.(no content)Lyapunov functions, named after Aleksandr Lyapunov, are scalar functions that may be used to prove the stability of an equilibrium of an ODE and are important to stability theory of dynamical systems and control theory.

## Related Concepts

Exponential stability is a form of asymptotic stability, valid for more general dynamical systems. Additionally, LaSalle's invariance principle is a criterion for the asymptotic stability of an autonomous (possibly nonlinear) dynamical system.

Links: [{"title":"Boolean network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_network"},{"title":"Boolean - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean"},{"title":"Logic synthesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logic_synthesis"},{"title":"Bayesian network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bayesian_network"},{"title":"Stochastic geometry models of wireless networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_geometry_models_of_wireless_networks"},{"title":"Gene regulatory network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gene_regulatory_network"},{"title":"File:Hou710 BooleanNetwork.svg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Hou710_BooleanNetwork.svg"},{"title":"Functional completeness - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complete_set_of_Boolean_operators"},{"title":"Boolean function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_function"},{"title":"Boolean circuit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_circuit"}]

## Boolean Network

A Boolean network is a particular kind of sequential dynamical system, where time and states are discrete, with the set of variables and the set of states in the time series each having a bijection onto an integer series.

### Key Characteristics

A Boolean network can exhibit stable, critical or chaotic behavior, governed by a critical value of the average number of connections of nodes.

### Historical Background

The first Boolean networks were proposed by Stuart A. Kauffman in 1969, as random models of genetic regulatory networks but their mathematical understanding only started in the 2000s.

### Applications in Biology

Boolean networks have been used in biology to model regulatory networks. Although Boolean networks are a crude simplification of genetic reality where genes are not simple binary switches, there are several cases where they correctly convey the correct pattern of expressed and suppressed genes.

In the context of gene regulatory networks, each node in the graph can be in one of two states: on or off. For a gene, "on" corresponds to the gene being expressed; for inputs and outputs, "on" corresponds to the substance being present. Time is viewed as proceeding in discrete steps. At each step, the new state of a node is a Boolean function of the prior states of the nodes with arrows pointing towards it.

### Types of Boolean Networks

Classical Boolean networks are synchronously updated. Deterministic asynchronous updated Boolean networks (DRBNs) are not synchronously updated but a deterministic solution still exists.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of network aggregation control:

## Link Aggregation Control

In computer networking, link aggregation is the combining (aggregating) of multiple network connections in parallel by several methods.(no content)Link aggregation increases total throughput beyond what a single connection could sustain, and provides redundancy where all but one of the physical links may fail without losing connectivity.

## Key Protocols

**Link Aggregation Control Protocol (LACP):** Within the IEEE Ethernet standards, the Link Aggregation Control Protocol (LACP) provides a method to control the bundling of several physical links together to form a single logical link.(no content)LACP allows a network device to negotiate an automatic bundling of links by sending LACP packets to their peer, a directly connected device that also implements LACP.

**Port Aggregation Protocol (PAgP):** Port Aggregation Protocol (PAgP) is a Cisco Systems proprietary networking protocol, which is used for the automated, link aggregation of Ethernet switch ports, known as an EtherChannel.

## Advanced Implementations

A multi-chassis link aggregation group (MLAG or MC-LAG) is a type of link aggregation group (LAG) with constituent ports that terminate on separate chassis, primarily for the purpose of providing redundancy in the event one of the chassis fails.

The search results also cover related technologies like carrier aggregation for wireless networks, frame aggregation for wireless LANs, and LTE-WLAN aggregation for mobile devices.

I've completed a web search on stochastic system stability. Here's what I found:

## Overview

A stochastic control problem is one in which the evolution of the state variables is subjected to random shocks from outside the system.(no content)Stochastic control or stochastic optimal control is a sub field of control theory that deals with the existence of uncertainty either in observations or in the noise that drives the evolution of the system.

## Stochastic Systems and Steady State

In stochastic systems, the probabilities that various states will be repeated will remain constant. This concept relates to achieving equilibrium despite randomness in the system.

## Key Concepts

Marginal stability is also an important concept in the context of stochastic dynamics. For example, some processes may follow a random walk. This equation has a unit root (a value of 1 for the eigenvalue of its characteristic equation), and hence exhibits marginal stability, so special time series techniques must be used in empirically modeling a system containing such an equation.

## Random Dynamical Systems

Formally, a random dynamical system consists of a base flow, the "noise", and a cocycle dynamical system on the "physical" phase space.(no content)The notion of an attractor for a random dynamical system is not as straightforward to define as in the deterministic case. For technical reasons, it is necessary to "rewind time", as in the definition of a pullback attractor.

## Control Design

In typical stochastic control problems, it is assumed that there exist random noise and disturbances in the model and the controller, and the control design must take into account these random deviations.

Formally, a random dynamical system consists of a base flow, the "noise", and a cocycle dynamical system on the "physical" phase space.(no content)The notion of an attractor for a random dynamical system is not as straightforward to define as in the deterministic case. For technical reasons, it is necessary to "rewind time", as in the definition of a pullback attractor.

## Control Design

In typical stochastic control problems, it is assumed that there exist random noise and disturbances in the model and the controller, and the control design must take into account these random deviations.

I've completed a web search on stochastic system stability. Here's what I found:

## Overview

A stochastic control problem is one in which the evolution of the state variables is subjected to random shocks from outside the system.(no content)Stochastic control or stochastic optimal control is a sub field of control theory that deals with the existence of uncertainty either in observations or in the noise that drives the evolution of the system.

## Stochastic Systems and Steady State

In stochastic systems, the probabilities that various states will be repeated will remain constant. This concept relates to achieving equilibrium despite randomness in the system.

## Key Concepts

Marginal stability is also an important concept in the context of stochastic dynamics. For example, some processes may follow a random walk. This equation has a unit root (a value of 1 for the eigenvalue of its characteristic equation), and hence exhibits marginal stability, so special time series techniques must be used in empirically modeling a system containing such an equation.

## Random Dynamical Systems

Formally, a random dynamical system consists of a base flow, the "noise", and a cocycle dynamical system on the "physical" phase space.(no content)The notion of an attractor for a random dynamical system is not as straightforward to define as in the deterministic case. For technical reasons, it is necessary to "rewind time", as in the definition of a pullback attractor.

## Control Design

In typical stochastic control problems, it is assumed that there exist random noise and disturbances in the model and the controller, and the control design must take into account these random deviations.
